question.title: Is it ok to suppress there warnings
question.body:
I have code that has two warnings.

The code is from a commandline Expense manager project that uses a List to save and access expenses. Saving and retrieving the List is done via serialisation and deserialisation of the List object

Serialisation:

try (FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream(SAVE_FILE);
             ObjectOutputStream oos = new ObjectOutputStream(fos)) {
            oos.writeObject(Expenses.getExpenses());
        }

Where Expenses.getExpenses() returns List<Expense>

Deserialisation:

        try (FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(SAVE_FILE);
             ObjectInputStream ois = new ObjectInputStream(fis)) {

            return (List<Expense>) ois.readObject();

        }

This one gives Unchecked cast from 'Object' to 'List<Expense>' warning

Another one is a warning from calling Thread.sleep inside a while loop. This is there to slowly print an ellipsis to the terminal dot by dot like a saving animation in the terminal.

try (ExecutorService service = Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor()) {
            Future<String> process = service.submit(() -> {
                Thread.sleep(2500);
                return "______________________";
            });

            while (!process.isDone()) {
                System.out.print(".");
                Thread.sleep(1000);
            }

This one says "Call to Thread.sleep() in a loop, probably busy waiting" I am new to asynchronous programming so I'm not sure if the warning is something that can be avoided.

The warnings do not interfere in any way with the function of the code but I would like to know if there's any solutions to clearing them and if not, is it ok to suppress the warnings with @SuppressWarnings.

question_comments.body: Serialize an array instead of a List. Then you will have no warnings. (That is, oos.writeObject(Expenses.getExpenses().toArray(Expense[]::ne‌​w));)

Generics don't exist at run time because all the type info is erased and its basically a List of Objects. You could try this: stackoverflow.com/a/26977424/16034206, basically check that the object is a list, then iterate all the elements of the list and verify each of the Object are actually Expense
